body:
There is nothing wrong in the custom symbol name but
```
julia> plot(r, decorated=(locations=a, symbol=(custom="arrow", size=0.3), fill=:black, dec2=true), Vd=1)
        psxy  -JX14c/0 -Baf -BWSen -R-10.4/10/-11/11 -S~f:+skC:\Users\joaqu\.julia\dev\GMT\share\custom\arrow/0.3+gblack -P -K > C:\TEMP\GMTjl_tmp.ps

psxy [WARNING]: Your filename @GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000288:+skC have what appears as valid GMT modifiers (from list +Udhinosu) but are embedded rather than appended to the filename - modifiers ignored
psxy [ERROR]: Libcurl Error: HTTP response code said error
psxy [ERROR]: Probably means @GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000288:+skC does not exist on the remote server
psxy [ERROR]: Unable to obtain remote file @GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000288:+skC
psxy [WARNING]: Your filename @GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000288:+skC have what appears as valid GMT modifiers (from list +Udhinosu) but are embedded rather than appended to the filename - modifiers ignored
psxy [ERROR]: Option -X: Cannot find/read fixed point file ~f@GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000288:+skC
psxy [ERROR]: No symbol specified!
```

comments_content.body: Sorry, is the **f** referring to fix points and those are given by a virtual file? So the _GMT_Encode_Options_ should turn that into `-S~f?:+sk` etc?

No, no virtual files here so the mention to them already indicate a stray path. If I change the code back to accept first custom files in current dir, then it works fine.

```
julia> plot(r, decorated=(locations=a, symbol=(custom="arrow", size=0.3), fill=:black, dec2=true), Vd=1)
        psxy  -JX14c/0 -Baf -BWSen -R-10.4/10/-11/11 -S~f:+skarrow/0.3+gblack -P -K > C:\TEMP\GMTjl_tmp.ps
```
Hm, if there are no virtual file, then were is the argument to **f**?
I mean, **f** takes a file name and if those locations are not provided by some virtual file then presumably you have an actual file name to give it, no?
I can debug this in Julia tomorrow if you provide what I need (e.g., a, arrow, ...)

But the complain is not on the locations (**f**) but on the custom symbol name. My second example works fine and I'm still passing the locations as an array.
``:+skC have what appears as valid GMT modifiers...``
``@GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000288:+skC does not exist on the remote server``

Sorry, perhaps I am confused, but your command needs two data files:

1. The data defining your line
2. The data defining your fixed points along the line for decorations

I assume `locations=a` sets the line? Where are the fixed points given?

And by the way, it is complaining about the fixed point file:

> Cannot find/read fixed point file

``a`` is the locations array (``r,a = streamlines(U, V);`` but you can't reproduce this yet). There is no problem with it. The problem is when I pass the custom's symbol full name.
```
julia> r,a = streamlines(U, V);
julia> plot(r, decorated=(locations=a, symbol=(custom="arrow", size=0.3), fill=:black, dec2=true), show=1)
```
![GMTjl_tmp](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/537321/166166641-94fd29cd-7971-4bc5-88f5-fec349d804b6.png)

Update the Julia wrapper.
Do:
```
x,y = GMT.meshgrid(-10:10); u = 2 .* x .* y; v = y .^2 - x .^ 2; U = mat2grid(u, x[1,:], y[:,1]); V = mat2grid(v, x[1,:], y[:,1]);
r,a = streamlines(U, V);
plot(r, decorated=(locations=a, symbol=(custom="arrow", size=0.3), fill=:black, dec2=true), show=1)
```
Now edit the file ``common_options.jl`` at line 2781
``if (GMTver < v"6.5.0" && startswith(marca, "karrow/"))``
and change "6.5.0" to "6.4.0". The above plot command won't work anymore and the reported error will show up.

You find ``common_options.jl`` in dir ``dirname(pathof(GMT))``

OK, you could speed this up a bit if you answered my questions. So **r** has the line coordinates and **a** has the points where you want arrows.  When I follow your steps I do crash but my error is different:

```
plot(r, decorated=(locations=a, symbol=(custom="arrow", size=0.3), fill=:black, dec2=true), show=1, Vd=1)
	psxy  -JX14c/0 -Baf -BWSen -R-10.4/10/-11/11 -S~f:+sk/Users/pwessel/.julia/packages/GMT/QLN4l/src/../share/custom/arrow/+gblack -P -K > /tmp/GMTjl_tmp.ps
psxy [ERROR]: Option -S~: Custom symbol /Users/pwessel/.julia/packages/GMT/QLN4l/src/../share/custom/arrow/ not given a valid size
```

The path looks OK since I can test it:

```
ls /Users/pwessel/.julia/packages/GMT/QLN4l/src/../share/custom/arrow*
/Users/pwessel/.julia/packages/GMT/QLN4l/src/../share/custom/arrow.def
```

However, the size argument is gone so it complains about that.  This is not the same you had above so not sure what is up with this.  I don't want to spent time debugging that when you do not see that problem on your end.

Sorry, that's the result of changes-over-changes-and-not-final-testing.
Change line 2784 to
```
marca = "k" * joinpath(dirname(pathof(GMT)), "..", "share", "custom", "arrow/") * marca[8:end]
```

I did answer your questions but you keep pointing to the locations array when there is no problem with it. The error messages refer to ``@GMTAPI@-S-I-D-D-T-N-000009:+skC`` but this means that the virtual memory address is glued with the beginning of the custom symbol file name and trimmed at the ``:`` of ``C:\...``
Ah, and if the ``:`` is the culprit in ``C:\...`` you may not have any error.
Yes, I think it is related to that - so I cannot easily simulate that here.  But I will stare at that code and see if there is any allowance for Bill's colon.
As you know, in these options the colon separates the directive from the options, so it should not be too hard to figure out how to handle that.
Given that it *forgive* the first colon I'd say it's looking backwards from the end of the line string and stop at first found.
Working on this now.  I am excluding colons (for this purpose) if followed by \ and preceeded by a letter.  Can the C in C:\ be lower case?
Yes, all ``c:/``, ``C:/``, ``c:\`` and ``C:\`` are allowed.
Thanks, PR coming very soon,

title: Someone is beeing too strict
